qas.question: What theory was Aristotle's explanation based on?

answers.text: his theory of potentiality and actuality

qas.question: How did Plato's Phaedo and Apology think of the mind?

answers.text: an entity that pre-existed somewhere in the heavens, before being sent down to join a body on Earth

qas.question: Who thought the senses were more important, Aristotle or Plato?
Who thought the senses were less important, Aristotle or Plato?
What does "nihil in intellectu nisi prius fuerit in sensu" mean?

answers.text: Latin for "nothing in the intellect without first being in the senses"

qas.question: Which commentator summarized a position in latin?

plausible_answers.text: the human mind as an entity that pre-existed somewhere in the heavens

qas.question: Why is Plato considered an empiricist?

plausible_answers.text: nothing in the intellect without first being in the senses

qas.question: What position by Plato was summarized by Middle Ages commentators?
Where did Aristotle say the human mind existed?

context: Aristotle's explanation of how this was possible was not strictly empiricist in a modern sense, but rather based on <a0_0>his theory of potentiality and actuality<a0_0/>, and experience of sense perceptions still requires the help of the active nous. These notions contrasted with Platonic notions of <b7_0>the human mind as <a1_0>an entity that pre-existed <b9_0>somewhere in the heavens<b9_0/><b7_0/>, before being sent down to join a body on Earth<a1_0/> (see Plato's <b6_0>Phaedo and Apology<b6_0/>, as well as others). <a2_0>Aristotle<a2_0/> was considered to give a more important position to sense perception than <a3_0><b5_0>Plato<b5_0/><a3_0/>, and commentators in the Middle Ages summarized one of his positions as "nihil in intellectu nisi prius fuerit in sensu" (<a4_0>Latin for "<b8_0>nothing in the intellect without first being in the senses<b8_0/>"<a4_0/>).
